Mudﬂow transport behavior and deposit morphology: Role of shear stress to yield
strength ratio in subaqueous experiments
Derek E. Sawyer a,⁎, Peter B. Flemings a, James Buttles b, David Mohrig a

a Jackson School of Geosciences, The University of Texas at Austin, University Station, Box X, Austin, TX, 78713, United States
b Bureau of Economic Geology, The University of Texas at Austin, University Station, Box X, Austin, TX, 78713, United States

Article history:
Received 31 October 2010
Received in revised form 29 January 2012
Accepted 30 January 2012
Available online 8 February 2012

The ratio of the shear stress to yield strength, deﬁned here as the ﬂow factor, controls a wide spectrum of mass
transport processes (slow, retrogressive failure to rapid, liqueﬁed ﬂows) and deposit morphologies (highly
fractured and hummocky to thin and smooth) in subaqueous dam-break experiments. We control pre-failure
ﬂow factor in sediment–water slurries by systematically varying water content and silt:clay fraction. We docu-
ment (1) the style and rate of sediment transport, and (2) the morphology of the entire deposit (source area
to down-dip extent) for low, medium, and high ﬂow factor slurries. A high ﬂow factor (shear stress≫yield
strength) generates a rapid collapse of the source area with an accelerating, long run-out ﬂow and a prominent
turbidity current. These ﬂows remove approximately 70% of the original source area volume within 10 s from
ﬂow initiation. These ﬂows leave behind a thin and smooth source area and deposit as a single mass that is
thin, long and wide. In contrast, a medium ﬂow factor (shear strength>yield strength) generates a slow retro-
gressive failure, in which individual fault blocks evacuate the source area and accumulate gradually over time
into a deposit. These ﬂows leave behind a blocky, highly fractured source area and construct short and thick
deposits with a hummocky surface. Lateral levees (characteristic of these ﬂows) focus material down-dip
while inhibiting lateral spreading, thus producing an elongated deposit. When ﬂow factor is low, approaching
unity (shear stress≈yield strength), only a narrow zone of failure occurs and a short and thick deposit is
constructed. Our experiments display characteristics similar to natural ﬁeld examples of submarine failures.
Our experiments suggest that a detailed analysis of deposit surface morphology from geophysical or outcrop
observations can yield important clues to the ﬂow history. In turn, this has practical implications for hazards
assessments and predictions in which it is important to consider how possible future failures may behave.

Submarine mudﬂows and debris ﬂows are ﬁne-grained, gravity-
driven, ﬂows having approximately equal parts water and solid by
volume (O'Brien and Julien, 1988; Iverson, 1997; Mohrig et al.,
1999). They are important sediment transport processes that redis-
tribute large volumes of sediment along continental margins. Evacua-
tion scars left behind by slope failures affect routing of subsequent
sediment ﬂows, including turbidity currents. (Hampton, 1972;
Embley, 1976; Aksu, 1984; Prior et al., 1984; Masson et al., 1997;
Urgeles et al., 1997; Gee et al., 1999; Elverhoi et al., 2002). Mudﬂows
may create tsunamis and coastal erosion, and damage seaﬂoor infra-
structure (Dugan and Flemings, 2000; Masson et al., 2006; Dan et
al., 2007; Zakeri et al., 2008).
The deposits of past mass movements are imaged in 3-D seismic
reﬂection data and record a wide variety of surface expressions and

deposit architectures (Piper et al., 1985; Mulder et al., 1997; Piper
et al., 1997; Gee et al., 1999; McAdoo et al., 2000; Mulder and
Alexander, 2001; Posamentier, 2003; Mosher et al., 2004; Pirmez et
al., 2004; De Blasio et al., 2005; Gee et al., 2006; Martinez et al.,
2006; Moscardelli et al., 2006; Minisini et al., 2007; Henrich et al.,
2008; Bull et al., 2009; Twichell et al., 2009). Despite the extensive
work characterizing these systems, it is still challenging to identify
the morphological elements that are most diagnostic of ﬂow behavior
and failure conditions. For example, some ﬂow deposits appear to
have moved a short distance from their source area with much of
the initial stratigraphy preserved. In other cases, ﬂows appear to
have traveled hundreds of kilometers in which the initial soil struc-
ture is completely remolded.
Mudﬂows occur within sediments of widely varying composition,
porosity, and shear strength, in all tectonic settings, and are triggered
by numerous mechanisms including sedimentation-induced over-
pressuring (Dugan and Flemings, 2000; Flemings et al., 2008; Stigall
and Dugan, 2010), gas-charging (Bunz et al., 2005), storm wave load-
ing (Seed, 1978; Rogers and Goodbred, 2010), salt diapirism (Orange
et al., 2003), earthquakes (Morgenstern, 1967; Hornbach et al., 2010;

Stigall and Dugan, 2010; Strozyk et al., 2010), and volcanic activity
(Moore et al., 1989). Although there are many modes of mudﬂows,
all initiate when the down-slope component of shear stress exceeds
the shear strength (Hampton, 1996; Iverson et al., 1997). The ratio
between the shear stress that drives ﬂow (τD) and the shear strength
that resists ﬂow (τR) is deﬁned here as the ﬂow factor (Ff)

The Ff is the inverse of the engineering factor-of-safety (ratio of
resisting strength to driving stress), which is the standard method
for evaluating stability of an intact slope (Lambe and Whitman,
1969). Here we are interested in behavior once failure occurs (when
factor-of-safety is less than 1) and ﬁnd it more intuitive that the
greatest potential to ﬂow is associated with the highest ratio. If Ff is
high (≫1), driving stress is much greater than resisting strength
and thus the potential to ﬂow is high. If Ff is low (~1), driving stress
is nearly equal to the resisting strength and thus a low ﬂow potential.
If Ff is less than 1, soil strength exceeds shear stress, and no ﬂow will
occur.
Direct observations of natural subaqueous ﬂows are not possible,
thus laboratory ﬂume studies and rheological models are the main
tools to explore dynamic mudﬂow behavior. Most ﬂume experiments
inject a sediment–water slurry down a slope to study ﬂow dynamics
over a wide range of conditions and sediment properties (Mohrig
et al., 1998; Marr et al., 2001; Ilstad et al., 2004; De Blasio et al., 2005).
However, this method does not capture the pre-failure or failure
processes and conditions that preceded the ﬂow. Experiments on
subaqueous sediment failures starting from an intact bed have been
described in several studies (Rettger, 1935; Einsele, 1974; Schwartz,
1982; Zreik, 1994; Zreik et al., 1995; Ancey and Cochard, 2009;
Cochard and Ancey, 2009). These experiments induce failure by tilting
a tabular sediment bed until failure occurs or with a ‘dam-break’ release
method in which a vertical wall is suddenly released in front of an
inclined tabular bed (Ancey and Cochard, 2009; Cochard and Ancey,
2009).
Geotechnical models rely on force balances to predict that ﬂow is
initiated from intact soil when shear stress exceeds the shear strength
(Hampton, 1972; Poulos, 1981; Schwab et al., 1988; Kayen et al.,
1989; Lee et al., 1991). Once ﬂow is established, it is commonly
assumed that the soil behaves as a non-Newtonian ﬂuid deﬁned by
a yield strength and viscosity (Johnson, 1970; Huang and García,
1999; Imran et al., 2001). These viscoplastic models simulate ﬂow
runout distance, ﬂow velocity, and deposit thickness based on the
yield strength and viscosity. These models however do not predict
the three-dimensional character or the ﬁne-scale surﬁcial features
of the ﬁnal deposit.
Here we trigger mudﬂows from static beds for which we know the
shear stress and shear strength a priori. We conduct subaqueous
experiments with mixtures of natural materials (kaolin clay, silt,

and water) using the dam-break method. We explore how the differ-
ence between shear stress and shear strength (Ff) controls the dy-
namic mudﬂow and the morphology of the deposit. We describe
our experimental methods and present dynamic behavior and depos-
it morphology of low, medium, and high Ff sediment–water mixtures.
A key result of our experiments is that low, medium, and high Ff
experiments produce unique transport behaviors and distinct deposit
morphologies. Furthermore, similar behaviors can be produced from
very different lithologies provided the Ff is similar. We discuss these
diagnostic features and processes and suggest this insight can guide
studies of past mudﬂows and hazard analyses of possible future mud-
ﬂows. A signiﬁcant component of this study was developing a meth-
odology to understand how different sediment mixtures behave as
they progress through failure and post-failure states.

The experimental sediment slurries are mixtures of natural kaolin
clay mined in Florida, U.S.A. (E.P. Kaolin clay) (Pirkle, 1960), silica silt,
and room temperature tap water. We characterize slurry rheology by
clay fraction (εc), water content (w), yield strength (τy), and
Herschel–Bulkley viscosity parameters K and n. We then calculate
the gravitational driving stress (τy) for each mixture for a subaqueous
10-cm thick bed sloping at 10°. Finally, we calculate Ff by the ratio of
the gravitational driving stress to yield strength. All experimental
values are reported in Table 1. All symbols are deﬁned in Table 2.

2.1.1. Grain size and water content
We used natural materials (kaolin clay, silica silt, and water) with
grain size distributions and water contents (porosity) that are repre-
sentative of ﬁeld conditions. Although we recognize that clay mineral
type plays a critical role in soil behavior, we chose to use a non-
swelling clay that is easier to work with in the laboratory and is
most commonly sued in other studies of subaqueous failures.
We measured the grain size distributions of the kaolin clay and the
silt with a standard hydrometer analysis (ASTM, 2007) (Fig. 1). By
mass, the kaolin clay is composed of 77% clay-sized particles
(b2 μm) and 23% silt-sized particles. The silt is composed of 90%
silt-sized and 10% clay-sized particles. The reported clay fraction
(εc) for each experimental slurry is corrected for the grain size distri-
bution of each component (Table 1). For example, a mixture of 75%
kaolin clay and 25% silt contains 60% clay-sized particles and 40%
silt-sized particles. Sediment with this grain-size distribution is clas-
siﬁed as a silty clay (Shepard, 1954). Thusεcis the percent by mass
of clay-sized particles to the mass of the solids.

We chose this water content range because it allowed the mixture
to be easily poured into the bed mold (as opposed to forming the bed
through particle settling), and to have a porosity (ϕ) characteristic of
natural mudﬂows (Keller et al., 1979; Einsele, 1990; Lee and Baraza,
1999; Sawyer et al., 2009).

2.1.2. Yield strength
We used a rotational viscometer (Fann model 35) to measure
yield strength (τy) of 29 slurries, each with different clay fraction
and water content. Viscometers are the most common tool to

Fig. 1. Hydrometer-derived grain size distribution of kaolin clay and silt. Silt:clay
boundary is deﬁned at 2 μm. The kaolin clay is composed of 77% clay-sized particles
and 23% silt-sized particles. The silt is composed of 90% silt-sized particles and 10%
clay-sized particles.

measure yield strength of ﬁne-grained sediment–water mixtures
(Major and Pierson, 1992; Coussot et al., 1998; Ilstad et al., 2004;
Zakeri et al., 2008).
All mixtures we tested have a shear-thinning rheology in which
the viscosity (slope of stress–strain curve) decreases as shear rate
increases (Fig. 2). Shear-thinning behavior is common for clayey
slurries and is also referred to as pseudoplastic and Casson behavior
(Locat and Demers, 1988; Phillips and Davies, 1991; Coussot and
Proust, 1996; Coussot et al., 1996; Locat, 1997; Coussot et al., 1998).
At each strain rate setting, we recorded shear stress readings at 20-
second intervals for a total 5 min. In all tests, the shear stress values
increased over time and in most cases reached steady state after
5 min. We plot the steady-state yield strength at each strain rate in
Fig. 2. To deﬁne τyat zero strain rate, we ﬁt each viscometer test
with a Herschel–Bulkley model:

τ ¼ τy þ Kγn;
ð5Þ

where τ is shear stress, K is apparent viscosity, γ is shear strain rate,
and n describes the rate of change of viscosity (n=1 for Bingham;
nb1 for shear-thinning).
Yield strength is inversely proportional to water content and pro-
portional to clay fraction (Fig. 3) as noted by previous authors (Marr
et al., 2001). As water content increases, the interaction between ad-
jacent particles decreases and thus yield strength decreases (Lambe
and Whitman, 1969). Clay minerals carry electrostatic forces that
can result in net attractive forces to increase yield strength (Craig,
1992). Therefore knowledge of composition or water content alone
is insufﬁcient for predicting yield strength and mudﬂow behavior.
As we will show, a given composition (clay-rich or silt-rich) can
exist as either low or high Ff, depending on the water content. Simi-
larly, a given water content can exist as low or high Ff depending on
its grain size distribution. The type of clay mineral plays a critical
role is soil behavior and yield strength (Lambe and Whitman,
1969), especially in the case of swelling clays (e.g., smectite). Howev-
er the value of the ﬂow factor ratio and its link to mudﬂow behavior is
applicable to any mixture.

The gravitational shear stress ﬂow (τg) is due to the weight of the
submerged bed inclined at 10°. We calculate τg assuming a 2-D inﬁ-
nite slope (Graham, 1984):

τg ¼ γbz sinθ cosθ;
ð6Þ

(10 cm), and θ is the bed slope (10°). The variation in w and grain

2.1.4. Flow factor
For each viscometer test we calculated Ff from Eq. (1); we used τg
andτy as the driving stress (τD) and resisting strength (τR) terms,
respectively. We then plot w versus εcand contour with respect to Ff
(Fig. 4). The advantage of the Ff contour plot is that we normalize
for the competing effects of clay fraction and water content. We use
Fig. 4 to predict that mixtures with equal Ff will produce similar styles
of mudﬂow despite having markedly different water contents and
compositions.
We selected 6 mixtures for mudﬂow experiments that covered the
wide range of Ff (Fig. 4). We arbitrarily deﬁned 3 Ff zones within
Fig. 4: high (Ff=~6), medium (Ff=~3), and low (Ff=~1). Experiment
lies within the high Ff zone, experiments 2 and 3 within the medium Ff
zone, and experiments 4–6 lie within the low Ff zone (Fig. 4).

Each experiment consists of 3 stages (Fig. 5). In Stage 1, we ﬁrst
mix silt, clay, and water in a concrete mixer for 45 min, then hand-
scoop the slurry from buckets into a horizontal aluminum-framed
plexi-glass inner tank to form a tabular bed 75 cm long, 24 cm wide,
and 10 cm thick (0.18 m3). The average total mass of clay, silt, and
water for each experiment was 45 kg. We then carefully smooth the
surface of the bed and place colored sand grains on the surface to
help visualize surface movements during the mudﬂow experiment.
We then ﬁll the outer tank with fresh water at room temperature to

We observed a continuum of dynamic behaviors and deposit mor-
phologies between high, medium, and low Ff experiments (Fig. 6).
High ﬂow factor (Ff=~6) produced a rapid collapse of the source
area with an accelerating ﬂow and an associated turbidity current,
and deposited a long and thin deposit en masse. Medium ﬂow factor
(Ff=~3) created a retrogressive mudﬂow in which many (~100)
small blocks detached from the source area and accumulated piece-
by-piece into one deposit. Finally, when Ff is low (Ff=~1), a blocky
failure occurs with very limited runout distance and volume. In the
following sections, we present details of high, medium, and low Ff
experiments; we focus on the dynamic response and the ﬁnal mor-
phology of the accumulated deposit and source area.

Experiment 1 had a high Ff of 6.23. The pre-failure sediment was
therefore very weak relative to the shear stress. As a result, a rapidly
moving mudﬂow (vp=16.3 cm/s) developed with a prominent tur-
bidity current (Fig. 6A). The event duration was 2.5 min during
which most of the original volume (70%) discharged from the source
area within the ﬁrst 10 s (Fig. 7 and Table 3). The ﬁnal volumetric dis-
tribution was 73% in the depositional lobe, 5% in the turbidity current,
and 22% remaining in the source area (Fig. 7).
The prominent turbidity current obscured our visual observations
of the mudﬂow body. As a result we did not see if the main body
hydroplaned as it traveled across the tank ﬂoor. However, the obser-
vation (Fig. 6) of a semi-detached section from the main deposit is
characteristic of decapitation that occurs in hydroplaning ﬂows. We
used the densimetric Froude number (FRd) to further explore the pos-
sibility that this ﬂow could have hydroplaned:

The source area is tabular and thin (~2 cm) (Fig. 7A). The surface con-
tains subtle closely-spaced fractures that penetrate b0.5 cm (Figs. 6D
and 7A). These fractures developed only at the very end of the mudﬂow
event and therefore are not associated with retrogressive failure.
The characteristic deposit features of Experiment 1 are the long
runout distance (140.2 cm) and very thin proﬁle (Fig. 8A, E, and
Table 3). The deposit contains subtle compression ridges in the cen-
tral area, which coincides with the break-in-slope (Fig. 9E). Other-
wise this deposit is remarkably smooth. The maximum deposit
thickness also occurs at the break-in-slope (Fig. 9A) and thins gradu-
ally to the end of the deposit. The L:W ratio of 1:3 indicates that the
longest dimension is in the dip direction.

Experiments 2 and 3 had medium Ff values of 3.53 and 3.05, re-
spectively. We discuss Experiment 3 in more detail but we point out
key differences between both experiments.
The dynamic response of Experiment 3 was retrogressive block
failure of the source area accompanied by piece-by-piece accumulation
in the depositional lobe over a period of 11.8 min (Figs. 6C, D and 7).
During the initial 30 s, the mudﬂow moved rapidly (vp=5.5 cm/s) but
thereafter discharge rate was constant (Fig. 7 and Table 3). Lateral
levees formed during lobe construction and channeled material down-
slope between levee margins (Fig. 6D). Levees limited lateral spreading
of the deposit and enhanced growth in the dip direction. The ﬁnal
volumetric distribution was 40% contained in the lobe deposit, 59%
in the source area, and 1% in a turbidity current (Fig. 7).
We discuss the evolution of the retrogressive failure of Experi-
ment 3 in more detail (Fig. 10). Within 5 s of ﬂow initiation, a prom-
inent headscarp formed ~25 cm upslope of the gate (Fig. 10B). A zone
of horst-graben structures and detached blocks developed between
this headscarp and the gate. As each block detached from the main
headscarp, it was progressively broken up into smaller blocks as it mi-
grated through the system and accumulated at the back of the lobe
deposit. With time, headwall retreat was balanced by downslope
movement and growth of the lobe deposit. Lateral levees formed
20 s after gate release (Fig. 10C). After 2.6 min, the entire source
area was an active zone of retrogressive failure (Fig. 10D). The lobe
continued to migrate downdip as it was pushed along by successive
evacuated blocks accumulating at the rear. As the lobe was being
pushed from behind, radial tension structures developed along the
front (Fig. 10D). The ﬁnal topography of the source area of experi-
ment 3 reﬂects the retrogressive failure process (Fig. 8A, C). Fracture
spacing is 2–3 cm and fracture depth is 1–2 cm.
The lobe deposit of Experiment 3 has a hummocky surface texture
(Figs. 6D, 9A, C and Table 3). Radial tension fractures occur along the
perimeter of the lobe. The blocky surface topography is the result of
the block-by-block construction process (Fig. 9A–C). The L:W ratio
for experiment 4 is 1:9, which indicates the longest dimension is
the along-ﬂow direction and is nearly twice the width. This reﬂects
the role of the lateral levees that acted to funnel material down-dip
and limited lateral growth. Total runout distance was 63.7 cm and
maximum lobe thickness was 1.9 cm (Table 3 and Fig. 9A).
Experiment 3 (Ff=3.53) was a medium Ff experiment but it
resulted in a run-out length that was nearly equal to the high Ff
experiment 1 (Fig. 9 and Table 3). However, this ﬂow behaved more

levees, and only generated a dilute turbidity current. We attribute the

Experiments 4–6 had low Ff values (b 2) (Table 1). However, only
Experiments 4 and 5 resulted in slope failure. The yield strength of
the mixture used in Experiment 6 was greater than the shear stress
(Ff=0.95) and thus produced no ﬂow. We discuss Experiment 4 in
detail because it is characteristic for this group.
Very slow-moving blocky failure occurred in Experiment 4 (Table 3;
Fig. 6A, B). The event lasted 2.5 min; 3 blocks evacuated the source area
and amalgamated into a single deposit. 2 suture lines deﬁne the loca-
tions of where the blocks joined (Fig. 6B). As each block impacted the
lobe, the entire lobe deposit was pushed along the bottom. As the lobe
advanced, it spread outwardly, which is recorded by radial tension
fractures that developed along the perimeter of the lobe (Fig. 6B).
Only 10% of the original source volume evacuated the source area
(Fig. 7). The peak and average ﬂow velocity (vp and va) was 0.8 cm/s
and 0.1 cm/s, respectively (Table 3).
The morphology of the source area records the limited retrogressive
failure process (Fig. 8A, B). The headwall marks the up-dip limit of
retrogression. Down-dip of the headwall is a zone (35% by area) of
detached fault blocks and grabens. Up-dip of the headwall is a smooth
and featureless zone (65% by area) that is nearly unaltered from its
pre-failure condition except for very subtle hairline cracks only visible
with the naked eye. In the zone of detached blocks, the fracture spacing
is 3–5 cm and penetration depth is limited to ~1 cm (Fig. 7A).
The deposit morphology records its depositional history (Figs. 6A,B,
9A,B). The depositional lobe contains 3 blocks. Each block is separated
by a suture line, which is imaged as a furrow oriented perpendicular

to ﬂow direction (Figs. 6A,B, 9A,B). Radial tension fractures are distrib-
uted along the perimeter of the toe. The total runout was 10.1 cm, and
maximum thickness was 4.5 cm. The lobe is longer in the strike direc-
tion indicated by an aspect ratio of 0.4 (Table 3).

We summarize the continuum of ﬂow behavior and deposit mor-
phology as a function of ﬂow factor. In all cases, mudﬂow begins
when the initial ﬂow factor is above 1 and ends when ﬂow factor
drops to 1. When the ﬂow factor is high (Ff>6) the driving stress is
much greater than the material strength, which results in a collapse of
the source area into a rapidly accelerating mudﬂow (possibly hydro-
planing) with a prominent turbidity current (Fig. 6A, B). The ﬂow evac-
uates rapidly from the source area, which drives the ﬂow factor to also
drop rapidly. The result is a rapid mudﬂow event but with a short dura-
tion (Fig. 7). The deposit is thin, and broad, with a smooth surface tex-
ture with very little surface relief. The source area contains only subtle
surface fractures (Fig. 6A). When initial ﬂow factor is intermediate
(Ff~3), a retrogressive failure process is established in which the master
headwall retreats up-dip at a moderate pace (Figs. 6C, D, 7). In these
cases, the ﬂow factor drops much more slowly than when ﬂow factor
is high. The result is a slower mudﬂow velocity but with a longer dura-
tion. The deposit develops lateral levees during its growth, which funnel
material downdip into a long and narrow deposit. Levees enhance run-
out by preventing lateral spreading of the ﬂow, thus maintaining a rel-
atively thick ﬂow, which in turn keeps Ff relatively high. Finally, when
the initial ﬂow factor is low, shear stress and resisting strength are near-
ly equal and the resulting failure is a slow-moving small-volume ﬂow
that is short-lived and does not generate a turbidity current (Fig. 6E,
F). It leaves behind a fractured source area with a master headwall
that does not retreat far up-dip. The length:width ratio is less than 1
indicating that the longest dimension in the strike direction.
In all experiments, the ﬂow factor progressively decreased during
the dynamic release phase and converged to a value of approximately

1, which marked the end of the mudﬂow event (Fig. 11). We calculat-
ed the theoretical ﬁnal bed thickness that each experiment would
converge to, assuming a ﬁnal ﬂow factor of 1, and plotted them
against the observed ﬁnal bed thickness (Fig. 11). The match is very
good for medium and high ﬂow factor experiments indicating that
these ﬂows stopped moving when the gravitational shear stress
dropped (via decrease in bed thickness) to a value equal to the
yield strength. For the low ﬂow factor experiments, this relationship
is more difﬁcult to discern because only the front portions of these
beds actually failed (Fig. 8). In cases where ﬂow factor is low, the
zone immediately adjacent to the stress-drop experiences failure
but far from the stress drop, the slope is essentially unaffected. This
is consistent with observations of ‘pinnacle’ failure blocks near a
prominent headscarp in the Gulf of Mexico (Sawyer et al., 2009).
From our experiments we elucidate relationships between the ini-
tial ﬂow factor and the resulting mudﬂow dynamics and morphology
(Fig. 12). Peak ﬂow velocity, runout distance, and volumetric dis-
charge decrease with decreasing values of Ff (Fig. 12A, B, C). This is
because as Ff decreases, the pre-failure material becomes stronger rel-
ative to the imposed shear stress. This suggests that if the shear stress
is more than twice the material yield strength, the mudﬂow can rap-
idly transport a large volume of material far from the source area.
Below this threshold a mudﬂow will deposit a relatively low volume
of material close to the source area. A more complex relationship ex-
ists for aspect ratio (L:W), deposit thickness, and mudﬂow duration
(Fig. 12D, E, F). The deposit aspect ratio is less than 1 for low Ff
(Ffb2), indicating the longest dimension is perpendicular to ﬂow. As-
pect ratio is greater than 1 for medium and high Ff, indicating that the
deposit is longer in the ﬂow-parallel direction. The peak in aspect
ratio (Fig. 12C) (experiment 3) is caused by lateral levees that
funneled material in the downdip direction while simultaneously
restricting lateral growth (Fig. 6D). At higher values of Ff, the material
yield strength is weak enough that the deposit can expand in the
strike direction nearly as much as it can in the downdip direction
(and no levees are formed), which results in aspect ratio only slightly
above 1. Deposit thickness increases slightly between Experiments 2
and 3 but decreases for higher Ff. This makes intuitive sense because
yield strength decreases as Ff increases. Finally, mudﬂow duration is
short at low and high Ff values and peaks at medium Ff values. The
peak value (Experiment 3) reﬂects the retrogressive failure that
lasted nearly 12 min. This suggests the longest duration ﬂows

The wide contrast in release mechanisms (Fig. 6), evacuation rate,
(Fig. 7) and style of deposition are important because knowledge of
the initial slide acceleration and volume are critical components for
modeling of the magnitude of slide-generated tsunami and impact
force on seabed infrastructure (Bondevik et al., 2005; Løvholt et al.,
2005; Zakeri et al., 2008). We observed two fundamentally different
release mechanisms: the high Ff experiment resulted in a high-
velocity, high-volume ﬂow and deposited en masse, most of which
occurred in the ﬁrst 10 s (Fig. 7). In contrast, the medium Ff mudﬂow
was a slow-velocity, low-volume retrogressive ﬂow that constructed
the ﬁnal deposit as piece-by-piece accumulation of ~100 small
detached blocks over a period of 11.8 min (Fig. 7). It is common to
assume the total volume of a slide deposit was deposited by a single
body, however it is clear that this assumption is not correct for retro-
gressive events.
Many of the world's large mass transport deposits (MTDs) display
a combination of features observed in our low, medium, and high Ff
experiments. For example, MTDs in the Gulf of Mexico (McAdoo et
al., 2000; Sawyer et al., 2009), and Storegga and other areas offshore
Norway (Bryn et al., 2005; De Blasio et al., 2005; Gauer et al., 2005;
Kvalstad et al., 2005), have headscarp regions that are characterized

by a broad zone of normal faults (similar to Experiment 3) that
evolved into long runout ﬂows (similar to Experiment 2 and perhaps
Experiment 1 in extreme cases (Talling et al., 2007)). However, in our
experiments, the broad zone of normal faults in Experiment 3 did not
evolve into long-runout ﬂows, nor did the liqueﬁed ﬂow of Experi-
ment 1 spawn from a retrogressive release mechanism in the source
area. A key difference in natural examples is likely strain weakening
of natural sediments, which has been shown to play a signiﬁcant
role in the post-failure behavior and morphology of large MTDs
(Kvalstad et al., 2005; Sawyer et al., 2009). These soils weaken after
peak strength is exceeded, which allows long runout ﬂows to evolve
from a low Ff state to a high Ff state. When failure initiates, ﬂow factor
is low because the shear stress has just exceeded the peak shear
strength, which forms fault blocks. However, as strain continues,
these materials progressively weaken under the imposed stress,
which increases the ﬂow factor (Eq. (1)), and allows the material to
evolve into long runout ﬂows.
The triggering mechanism will play a key role in determining Ff
in natural cases. For example, in the cases of a gradual forcing, such
as tectonic-induced oversteepening or sedimentation-induced over-
pressuring, failure will occur when the driving stress just exceeds
resisting

(e.g.,

induced), Ff may be signiﬁcantly higher than 1, depending on the
exact nature of the triggering event, and thus may generate ﬂows
characteristic of the high Ff experiments (1 and 2). One might expect
that passive margin settings would be dominated by low Ff ﬂows and
active margins would be characterized by high Ff ﬂows. Yet all conti-
nental margins show a broad spectrum of ﬂow styles, which reﬂects
the complex interplay of the numerous processes that govern the ac-
tual Ff in nature.
Our experiments are a ﬁrst order test of the response of ﬂows
when Ff is low, medium, and high. In the experiments we quantiﬁed
the driving stress, resisting strength, and thus Ff a priori, which
allowed us to link the value of Ff to the resulting dynamic mudﬂow
response and the morphology of the deposit. In natural cases we are
left with the deposit morphology to infer possible conditions of
strength and stress at failure.
We suggest that the Ff can be a useful metric for interpreting, in a
relative sense, the linkage between ﬂow transport behavior and de-
posit morphology. However, scaling-related issues are inherent to
geomorphic experiments such as these that use small-scale laborato-
ry experiments to infer ﬁeld-scale processes (Mohrig et al., 1999;
Parsons et al., 2001; De Blasio et al., 2004; Ilstad et al., 2004; Paola
et al., 2009).We discuss the limitations of our experiments in light
of these challenges but ultimately the ratio of driving stress to resist-
ing strength is key to the transport behavior and deposit morphology
in the experimental and natural scales. The low stress levels imposed
in our set-up means that cohesion is potentially a signiﬁcant compo-
nent of slurry strength. In natural-scale ﬂows involving 10s–100s of
meters of vertical thickness, cohesion is negligible compared to the
frictional component. Furthermore, the experimental slurries used
here have uniform properties over the 10-cm thick bed. Natural soil
properties may vary signiﬁcantly over 10s–100s of meters of vertical
thickness. In addition, the experimental slurries we used are not
strain weakening soils, which may be a signiﬁcant factor controlling
morphology and transport style of large-scale retrogressive MTDs.
The ‘dam-break’ ﬂow triggering mechanism used in our experiments
is not the most relevant to natural triggering mechanisms but our
main goal was to hold the release mechanism constant while explor-
ing a range of deposit strengths. The ﬂows in our experimental tank
were initially restricted in the tank but once evacuated, had no re-
strictions laterally, nor encountered any ﬂow obstacles. However,
the change in slope to 0° did cause a different shear stress regime
than the part of the ﬂow on the 10° slope. However, the experiments
here are a ﬁrst-order test of the dynamic and morphological response

of the magnitude of the yield strength as it relates to the shear stress.
It is the ratio of these that dictates ﬂow behavior and morphology in
our experiments and we suggest in natural ﬂows as well. Finally, we
rely on the concepts presented by Paola et al. (2009) that, although
most geomorphic experiments are not dynamically scaled, they do
simulate spatial geometry and kinematics of natural systems and
therefore can illuminate the critical linkages between landscape evo-
lution and sedimentary processes.

Our experiments illuminate how the difference between yield
strength and ﬂow-inducing shear stress controls mudﬂow dynamic
behavior and deposit morphology. When this difference is small,
yield strength and shear stress are nearly equal, which results in a
slow moving, low-volume, mudﬂow that retrogressively fails from
the source area. The deposits grow piecewise as each fault block
detaches from the source and accumulates at the back of the deposit.
As the difference between yield strength and shear stress increases,
mudﬂows become progressively weaker and thus produce longer-
runout, higher-volume ﬂows. The ﬂows move, and emplace, as a sin-
gle body. Detailed analysis of deposit morphology can yield important
clues to the depositional history of the ﬂow. This has important impli-
cations for hazards assessments, including slide-generated tsunami
modeling, which rely heavily on the initial release mechanism and
volumes of the slide.
